Package com.esri.mo2.src.file

Implementation of the Content API for the file system.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
FileContent Content that represents a file
FileHandler FileHandlers provide a generic way to obtain the content provided by a FileFolderConnection.
 

Class Summary
FileSystemConnection This connection provides access to the Source representing the local file system.
FileSystemContentProvider This is the ContentProvider for the file system
FileSystemSource This Source provides access to the Content found in the local file system.
FileUtility this class provides support for handling files
 

Package com.esri.mo2.src.file Description

Implementation of the Content API for the file system. Applications can connect to file-based objects, such as a FeatureClass or a FeatureLayer, using this implementation. A typical sequence for accessing Content that represents a particular file-based Dataset is like this: 

   Connection connection = new FileSystemConnection();
   Source source = SourceCache.getSource(connection);
   // there is no need to call source.connect()
   // as the FileSystem Source is always connected
   Content content = source.getContent("path to content");
   // there is no need to call source.disconnect()
   // as the FileSystem Source always remains connected
Content paths have the same form as file system paths, except that a forward "/" should be used as separator. Content paths are case insensitive. The simplest way to ensure that the correct path is used to access a particular content is to view the path to the content shown in the Catalog component - for instance, when used within the JoViewPlus sample application. Content path for a particular file-based datasource should include primary file's extension.

Several file-based datasources are supported. For the complete list of currently supported file formats see "Supported data formats section" in the "Information Resources" chapter of Online User's Reference.

If a data source supports layers with multiple geometry types than content path must include the feature type at the end. Multiple geometry types are supported by CAD. For example, a content path for accessing specific data in CAD datasource may look as follows:
"C:/MOJ20_final/MOJ20/Samples/Data/CADdata/parcels.dwg/Annotation"
"C:/MOJ20_final/MOJ20/Samples/Data/CADdata/parcels.dwg/Polygon"
"C:/MOJ20_final/MOJ20/Samples/Data/CADdata/parcels.dwg/Polyline"
"C:/MOJ20_final/MOJ20/Samples/Data/CADdata/parcels.dwg/Point"

To connect to VPF and RPF datasources the corresponding content path must include system path to the folder with the datasource followed by the name of the particular layer. For example, the path "C:/Leonid/Data/vpf_rpf_data/EURNASIA2/rference:dbref:dbref" connects to the layer "rference:dbref:dbref" in the directory "C:\Leonid\Data\vpf_rpf_data\EURNASIA2\".

Developers can optionally add support for more file formats by implementing the FileHandler interface, then using the various FileHandler management methods located within the FileSystemSource class.
